{{URL|http://www.aldeparty.eu/}}

article.paragraph: TheAlliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe Party(ALDE Party) is aEuropean political partymainly active in theEuropean Union, composed of 60 national-levelLiberalismliberalparties from across Europe. Until 10 November 2012, the party was known asEuropean Liberal Democrat and Reform Party(ELDR).cite webhttp://www.eldr.eu/en/press-releases/european-liberal-democrats-change-party-name-alde-party-0European Liberal Democrats change party name to ALDE Party | ALDE PartyEldr.eu2013-09-23The ALDE Party is affiliated with theLiberal International.http://www.liberal-international.org/site/Co-operating_Organsisations.html

Having developed from a loose confederation of national political parties in the 1970s, the ALDE Party is a recognised European political party incorporated as a non-profit association underlaw of BelgiumBelgian law.

as of2015, ALDE is the third largest European-wide political party represented in European Union institutions, with 70Member of the European ParliamentMEPsand 5 members of theEuropean Commission. Of the 28member states of the European UnionEU member states, there are seven with ALDE-affiliated Prime Ministers:Xavier Bettel(Democratic Party (Luxembourg)DP)inLuxembourg,Charles Michel(Mouvement RformateurMR) inBelgium,Taavi Rivas(Estonian Reform PartyRE) inEstonia,Miro Cerar(Stranka Mira CerarjaSMC) inSlovenia,Juha Sipil(Centre Party (Finland)KESK) inFinland,Mark Rutte(People's Party for Freedom and DemocracyVVD) in theNetherlandsandLars Lkke Rasmussen(Venstre (Denmark)Venstre) inDenmark. Liberals are also in government in three other EU member states:Croatia,Czech RepublicandLithuania.

Since 20 July 2004, the ALDE Party is politically represented in theEuropean Parliamentby theAlliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe GroupAlliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe(ALDE)Political groups of the European Parliamentparliamentary group, formed in conjunction with theEuropean Democratic Party(EDP). The ALDE parliamentary group is led byGuy Verhofstadt, a formerPrime Minister of Belgium. Prior to theEuropean Parliament election, 20042004 European electionthe party was attached to theEuropean Liberal Democrat and Reform Party (European Parliament group)European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party(ELDR) Group.

The youth wing of ALDE is theEuropean Liberal Youth(LYMEC), which is predominantly based upon youth and student liberal organisations but contains also a small number of individual members. LYMEC is led by Vedrana Gujic (Croatian People's Party Liberal DemocratsHNS, Croatia), who was elected for a two-year term as LYMEC President in May 2014, and counts 200,000 members.

article.heading: History of pan-European liberalism

template.arg: History of pan-European liberalism

article.paragraph: Pan-European liberalism has a long history dating back to the foundation of Liberal International in April 1947. In March 1976, the Federation of Liberal and Democrat Parties in Europe was established. The founding parties of the federation were theFree Democratic Party (Germany)Free Democratic Partyof Germany,Radical Party (France)Radical Partyof France,Liberal Party (Denmark)Liberal Partyof Denmark,Italian Liberal Party, DutchPeople's Party for Freedom and DemocracyandDemocratic Party (Luxembourg)Democratic Partyof Luxembourg.cite bookDimitri AlmeidaThe Impact of European Integration on Political Parties: Beyond the Permissive Consensushttp://books.google.com/books?id2012Taylor & Francis978-1-136-34039-0102–103Observer members joining later in 1976 were theDanish Social Liberal Party, FrenchRadical Party of the LeftandIndependent Republicans, BritishLiberal Party (UK)Liberal Party, andItalian Republican Party.The federation gradually evolved into the European Liberal Democrat and Reform Party (ELDR) with a matching group in the European Parliament, theEuropean Liberal Democrat and Reform Party (European Parliament group)European Liberal Democrat and Reform PartyGroup.

At an extraordinary Congress in Brussels held on 30 April 2004 the day before theenlargement of the European Union, the ELDR Party incorporated itself under Belgian law and became aEuropean political party.

The ELDR Party allied with theEuropean Democratic Partyin 2004 to form theAlliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe(ALDE), with a matchingAlliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe GroupALDE Group in the European Parliament. The ELDR Party adopted its current name on 10 November 2012 in order to match the pan-European alliance and parliamentary group.
